description: Borrowed from French terrain, from Latin terrenum (“land, ground”), neuter of terrenus (“consisting of earth”), from terra (“earth”).

entries.meaning: (geology) A single, distinctive rock formation; an area having a preponderance of a particular rock or group of rocks.
An area of land or the particular features of it.
examples: The race will be run over a variety of terrain, including grass and sand.

entries.meaning: (chiefly aviation) The surface of the earth; the ground.
examples: This approach requires the aircraft to stay at an altitude of at least 3000 feet MSL until crossing the VOR in order to maintain terrain clearance.
